stem: The nurse is reviewing hemodynamic parameters for a client in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). For each set of parameters, select the shock state that it most likely represents.

rows.text: Low CVP, Low PAWP, Low Cardiac Output (CO), High SVR.
High CVP, High PAWP, Low CO, High SVR.
Low CVP, Low PAWP, High CO, Low SVR.
High CVP, Normal PAWP, Low CO, High SVR (Right heart failure focus).

rationale.correct: Hemodynamic patterns guide resuscitation. (r1) Hypovolemia = Low volume (Low CVP/PAWP) and compensatory clamping (High SVR). (r2) Cardiogenic = High 'back-pressure' volume (High CVP/PAWP) due to pump failure. (r3) Septic = Massive vasodilation (Low SVR) and high compensatory flow (High CO). (r4) Right-sided failure elevates CVP (right heart pressure) while the CO remains low.
rationale.incorrect: SVR is exclusively low in distributive (Septic, Anaphylactic, Neurogenic) shocks.
clinicalPearls: Septic shock is the only major shock state characterized by a LOW Systematic Vascular Resistance (SVR).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that in early (warm) sepsis, the heart pumps faster to compensate for low resistance. High CO with low SVR is the 'signature' of sepsis.

reviewUnits.heading: Hemodynamic Monitoring in Shock
reviewUnits.body: Nurses use CVP (Right heart), PAWP (Left heart), and SVR (Vessel tension) to differentiate shock causes. Management varies from fluid in hypovolemia to inotropes in cardiogenic shock.
